_prev_prog_3.Description: Watts Bros. Frozen Foods complies with the prevention program level 3 requirements found in the WISHA PSM standard 296-67.  This program is organized into the following elements: 1) Employee participation in the elements of this safety and release prevention program wherever possible; 2) Training provided for operators and maintenance personnel; 3) Process Safety Information (PSI) maintained on ammonia hazards and the refrigeration system; 4) Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the refrigeration system conducted and periodically reviewed to ensure adequacy of controls; 5) Mechanical Integrity program to ensure the system continues to operate as designed; 6) Operating and Maintenance procedures to provide operators and maintenance staff the information necessary to safelyoperate and maintain the system; 7) Selection of Contractors working on or near the refrigeration system qualified to ensure safety performance, and briefed on the hazards and safety requirements of the job; 8) Hot Work Permits required whenever welding, cutting, grinding or other activities are conducted that could generate sparks and start a fire; 9) The Management of Change (MOC) program requiring that the impact of changes to the refrigeration system be evaluated and approved prior to the work being conducted; 10) Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) conducted prior to restart of the system after modifications to ensure that impacts of the change are addressed; 11) Incident investigations conducted for incidents involving ammonia releases and near misses that endanger employees or the public; 12) Compliance Audits conducted every three years to ensure that the prevention program is meeting its objectives; 13) Emergency Planning and Response ensuring that employees and emergency personnel are prepared to respond to an ammonia release in accordance with the plant's emergency plan and that notifications are made to designated points of contact at local, state, and federal levels depending on the extent of the release.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Watts Brothers Frozen Foods, LLC (hereafter "WBFF"), based in Paterson, WA, processes fresh vegetables obtained from multiple growing sites into frozen vegetable products for sale in commercial markets. Ammonia is used as a refrigerant in the freezing process. Ammonia is a colorless gas with a pungent odor that is an irritant to the eyes, nose and throat. It is normally shipped as a liquefied compressed gas and is present in portions of the refrigeration system as a liquid under pressure. Please refer to onsite data for ammonia quantities.

The Paterson plant is located in a highly rural area with virtually no residential properties within the toxic endpoint distance for any ammonia release which would be likely to occur. A moderately busy highway (U.S. HWY.14) runs in an east-west direction within a few hundred yards of the WBFF facility.

In order to protect its employees, the public, and the environment, WBFF is developing an integrated safety management program to prevent ammonia releases and mitigate the consequences of a release, should one occur. This program is contained in a comprehensive web-based format designed to comply with WISHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standards found in WAC 296-67 and EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations found in 40 CFR Part 68. This safety management website is currently under construction with all elements scheduled to be in place by 12/31/04. When completed, the website will be a valuable tool through which WBFF will be able to document any changes in safety or emergency procedures immediately upon their adoption.   

Off Site Consequence (OCA) data is available for review onsite at the WBFF processing plant.

The Paterson plant has an emergency plan that addresses the response necessary for a release of ammonia from the refrigeration system.  Any leak is easily detected through the plant ammonia detection equipment, and WBFF maintains a staff of  operations and maintenance personnel who are trained and qualified

to respond to leaks of ammonia.  The refrigeration system is designed so that major components can be isolated by closing selected valves.  In case of a release that could travel off the plant property, calls would be made to the Paterson fire department, and the Benton County Disaster Services Coordinator to assist in the response.  Other state and federal notifications would be made as required.

The Paterson plant has experienced only infrequent minor releases that have never been detected beyond the plant boundaries.  During the last five years, there have been no reportable releases of ammonia.
